results.title: A Telephone call for Genevieve Snow
results.creator_credit: Blackout Productions, Beth Frey and Peter Long
results.brief_description: Genevieve Snow (Beth Buchanan) is a mousey piano teacher at a primary school ruled by a formidable headmistress, in this revisionist version of the Little Red Riding Hood fairytale based on a short story by Carmel Bird. One day as he is driving past the school, Nigel hears Genevieve being summoned over the public address system and decides to call her and through the series of elliptical phone conversations that follow, the pair strike up a strange relationship. Yet Genevieve’s lonely desperation and Nigel’s odd canine obsessions suggests their mutual attraction may have fatal consequences. Moody black and white photography emphasises these sinister undertones, yet the gothic atmosphere of this seemingly cautionary tale is shot through with a sense of the absurd, especially in relation to the claustrophobic rituals that enforce conventional roles. Cast also includes Damien Richardson, Esme Melville. Awards: Silver Lion for best short film in competition 57th Venice Film Festival 2000.

results.title: A Taxing woman's return
results.creator_credit: Itami Productions, Yasushi Tamaoki and Juzo Itami
results.brief_description: A follow uo to his comedy film “A Taxing woman”, Itami satirises the collapse of traditional values in Japan since World War II. Ryoko Hakura, the resourceful tax inspector inspired by the american “Colombo”, takes on the financial labyrinthe constructed by a jaded leader of a fraudulent religious cult collaborating with politicians, banks, big business; all held together by organised crime. This is a world peopled with “off-centre” characters who possess a gammut of short comings, cleverly satirised. The pace of the film is frantic; the plot, an intricate blend of comedy and action.

results.title: A Taxing woman
results.creator_credit: Yasushi Tamaoki, Seigo Hosogoe and Juzo Itami
results.brief_description: Evading taxes is a popular pastime in “The Land of the Rising Yen”, especially among the predatory real estate tycoons who, in collusion with politicians, gangsters and large “straight” business combines, have made Japan’s land prices the highest in the world. To combat this pandemic “lawlessness” there is a national tax police, who, with their almost storm trooper tactics, make America’s much maligned IRS inspectors seem almost helpful. In Japanese with English subtitles.

results.title: A taste of Hong Kong (Captioned)
results.brief_description: This video, which has detailed demonstrations of traditional Chinese dishes and garnishes, is interspersed with views of life in Hong Kong, particularly the markets, the restaurants and the harbour. It is divided into five sections: “Delights of the heart” which covers breakfasts and dim sum, “Treasures from the sea”, “Meat roasts”, “Food and festivals” and “Homecooking”. Demonstrated dishes include spare ribs en papillotte, sauteed oysters with spring onion and ginger, roast pork and duck and spiced crispy chicken.

results.title: A Taste of energy
results.creator_credit: Scope Films, Colonial Sugar Industry and Edwin Scragg
results.brief_description: The Australian sugar industry, showing all stages of cane cultivation and harvesting, extraction and refining of sugar. Impressions of life in the sugar producing regions of Queensland and northern New South Wales and the place of sugar in the Australian economy.

results.title: A taste of China: cooking with Kenneth Lo
results.creator_credit: Thames Video Collection and Eddie Joffe
results.brief_description: Kenneth Lo, world famous Chinese chef and leading authority on Chinese food, is joined by actor Vincent Price on this Chinese cookery course. Chinese cuisine is one of the oldest in the world, with many contrasts in flavour, colour and texture. Kenneth Lo unlocks the secrets and mysteries of this cuisine and provides straightforward instructions for basic methods of preparing a Chinese family meal or elaborate banquet. Chefs from Lo’s cooking school appear on this video, preparing a range of delicious recipes.

results.title: A Taste of cherry = Ta'm e guilass
results.brief_description: Abbas Kiarostami’s `Taste of Cherry’, the 1997 Palme d’or winner at the Cannes Film Festival, follows his usual style of fiction bordering on documentary. A weary middle-aged man drives his car around looking for someone to bury him after he kills himself. He meets different people - Afghans, Kurds, a soldier, a cleric, a museum employee - all of whom try to dissuade him from his intent. This film presents a minimalist meditation on life and death, deliberately avoiding emotions or judgements. The ending is cut short due to a state prohibition on the depiction of suicide.
